STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 29, 2023
Annetra Bennett
Samaritas - Southeast
8131 E. Jefferson Ave.
Detroit, MI, 48214-2610
RE: License#: CB820201265
Dear Ms. Bennett
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Linda Tansil, area manager at 248-860-0787.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
Pontiac, MI 48342
brownp2@michigan.gov
(248) 860-3012

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) (b)
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once 90 calendar days
t hereafter.
One of six foster care files reviewed for updated service plans contained late
service plans. Service plan report ending with 12/4/22 was five days late and
service plan ending with 6/15/23 was eighteen days late.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/27/21 RENEWAL, CAP approval 10/12/21
12/14/22 INTERIM, CAP approval 4/4/23 – due to CWLM system change
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) (o)
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be
recorded within 30 calendar days after placement
in independent living and updated at least once
every 90 calendar days:
(o) servie plans as required in R 400.12419 and
400.12420….

Three of three independent living case files reviewed contained late updated
service plans. One youth updated service plan ending 12/20/22 was twelve days
late, same youth updated service plan report ending 6/13/23 was seven days late,
same youth udpated service plan report ending 9/15/23 was one day late. Second
youth updated service plan report ending 7/27/23 was one day late. Third youth
updated service plan report ending 7/20/23 was one day late.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/27/21 RENEWAL, CAP approval 10/12/21
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement.
(2)
(2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the
youth and the social services worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at least
once every 90 calendar days and a copy provided to
the youth.
One of three independent living case files reviewed, one did not contain a
independent living agreement signed and dated every 90 days.
FOM POLICY 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames
as outlined in the following tables: Case Plan
Development/Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP) –
within 30 calendar days before the case plan due
date. Updated Service plan (USP) – within 30
calendar days before the Case Plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
days before the case plan due date.
Two of nine updated Service Plan case files reviewed (6 Foster Care Case Files,
3 Independent Living Case Files) did not document timely Family Team Meeting
occuring. One Foster Care case file did not have a FTM for the report period
ending 2/27/23. One Independent Living case file report ending 6/5/23 document
the FTM on 6/21/23 after the reporting period.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/27/21 RENEWAL, CAP approval 10/12/21
12/14/22 INTERIM, CAP approval 4/4/23 – due to CWLM system change

FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans Agreement and Signaure.
Once completed and approved, the caseworker
Must obtain signatures from the following
individuals as applicable:
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and
unrelated court ordered caregivers.
Six foster care case files, three independent living case files (thirty- four PATP’s)
reviewed, seventeen PATP’s were late or missing from the youth case files.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/27/21 RENEWAL, CAP approval 10/12/21
12/14/22 INTERIM, CAP approval 4/4/23 – due to CWLM system change
FOM POLICY 801-03 Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child’s current and complete health
information.
One of six foster care case files reviewed did not have a quarterly updated medical
passport.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/27/21 RENEWAL, CAP approval 10/12/21
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• No technical assistance was provided.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• No consultation was provided.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
agency submitted three approved acceptable corrective action plans during this
reporting period.
Special Investigation #2023C0000054 was completed on 3/6/23, CAP was
accepted on 4/5/23. The agency was in violation with R400.12409 (1) Education
and DHHS FOM 722.03F Approved absences from foster care placement. The
agency has followed their CAP with this violation.
Special Investigation #2023C00000373 was completed on 5/2/23, CAP was
accepted on 5/16/23. The agency was in violation with R400.12421 (1) (a)
Visitation and parenting time. The agency has followed their CAP with this
violation.
Renewal Inspection was completed on 2/14/23 and the CAP was accepted on
4/4/23. The agency was in violation with Rules 400.12212 (2) (g) Personnel
records, 400.12418 (2) (b) Development of service plans and DHHS FOM policies
722-6B Family Team Meeting, 722.08C Foster care parent agency treatment plan
and service agreement, and 722.08D Treatment plans agreement and signatures.
The agency has some repeat violations with this renewal period.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator discussed during the exit conference that stabilization of
teams has been the agency priority, staff turnover continues to be a challenge.
The CA reported that supervisors have been overwhelmed with supervision of
their teams and carrying caseloads at the same time. It was reported that the
2021-2022 CAP has resulted in some improvements in the management,
oversight, and tracking. It was reported that significant efforts have been made to
ensure that internal procedures result improved compliance. However, frequent,
and sudden turnover continues to present ongoing challenges with consistency.
Efforts to decrease and eliminate supervisor's carrying cases are ongoing and
expected to have a positive impact on their ability to better monitor their teams to
ensure that internal policies and procedures are being carried out effectively.
Financial Overview
The agency provided their annual audit by an independent certified public
accountant and the annual budget for the current fiscal year. No concerns were
noted.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The staff interviewed enjoy working with their coworkers and had high praises for
their immediate supervisors and stated that their supervisors is always there to

lend a shoulder to cry on when the staff feels stress, the work becomes
overwhelming, or they are burnt out with the process. The staff reported the
administration supports the hard work they do with the families and children they
serve and that they feel strongly that the administration cares about their mental
health. The staff interviewed stated they would love to see more resources
available for their youth in the independent living programs. Staff suggested
having a lower caseload so they could focus more on the families on their
caseload. The staff interviewed also suggested that the agency recruit interns to
support the workers with transportation. The staff interviewed suggested that with
the lowering of the caseloads and hiring interns, this will assist in helping the
agency gain retention of their staff.
No youth was interviewed by this Consultant.
Description of Agency Walk Through
There were no areas of safety concerns when toured the staff offices and other
areas in the facility.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts during this renewal period.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that Samaritas - Southeast will be issued a renewal of their regular
license.
9/29/2023
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
10/01/2023
Linda D Tansil Date
Area Manager
